contentrichtext.text: {{BLP IMDB refimprove|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox person |name = Hal Douglas |image = |caption = Douglas at work |birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1924}} |birth_place = [[Stamford, Connecticut|Stamford]], [[Connecticut]] }} '''Hal Douglas''' (born 1924) is a retired [[United States|American]] [[voice actor]] best known for his work on [[movie trailers]] and [[television commercial]]s. ==Life and career== Douglas was born in [[Stamford, Connecticut|Stamford]], [[Connecticut]], served in [[World War II]], and attended the [[University of Miami]] in [[Florida]] as a drama major. He began a career in radio in the 1950s. By the 1960s, he had become a producer for several prominent advertising agencies in [[New York City]]. He finally moved into doing [[voice-overs]] for commercials, promos, and trailers by the early 1970s, and would continue doing so until the late 2000s. Because many of his trailers have begun with the words "In a world", there is controversy over whether his voice has immortalized them ([[Don LaFontaine]] claimed to have actually created the catchphrase). In addition, Douglas has been the promotional voice for the former [[WB Television Network|WB]], [[A&E Network|A&E]], [[Disney Channel]]'s "Vault Disney" (1997â€“2002), and [[History (U.S. TV channel)|The History Channel]]. He did the voiceover narration for the Detroit Red Wings 1997, and the 1996 Chicago Bulls championship documentaries. Because he has recorded so many trailers through the years, he has sometimes been mistaken for [[Don LaFontaine]]. He can be seen [[parodying]] himself in the trailer for ''[[Comedian (movie)|Comedian]]'', a documentary that features [[Jerry Seinfeld]]. Douglas provided narration for the trailer for the novel ''All The Talk Is Dead'' by Michael Ebner. Unlike most movie trailer announcers, Douglas lives in [[Northern Virginia|Northern]] [[Virginia]] and his agent is based in [[New York City]] instead of [[Los Angeles]]. Hal Douglas has been described by a [[Miramax]] publicist as "perhaps the most recognizable trailer voice in the business." ===5 Men and a Limo=== Douglas's voice briefly appears in the skit ''[[5 Men and a Limo]]'', featuring other notable voiceover recording artists, such as [[Don LaFontaine]], John Leader, [[Nick Tate]], [[Al Chalk]], and [[Mark Elliot (voice-over artist)|Mark Elliot]]. ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0235069|name=Hal Douglas}} * [http://voicechasers.com/database/showactor.php?actorid=5236 Hal Douglas] at [http://voicechasers.com Voice Chasers] {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Douglas, Hal | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1924 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Connecticut]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Douglas, Hal}} [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:American voice actors]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Radio and television announcers]]
